results.title: Faces
results.brief_description:
Sue Ford’s experimental film “Faces” consists of portraits of the artist and her friends and acquaintances. Ford filmed each subject for roughly 25 seconds, using a wind-up Bolex camera that framed their faces in close-up. Variously self-conscious, serious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.

results.title: Egami
results.creator_credit: Victorian Women's Film Unit and Sue Ford
results.brief_description: In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Melbourne landmarks are totalitarian monuments, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.

constellations_primary.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_primary.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian Women’s Film Unit and Sue Ford
results.description: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.
description_for_label: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.

results.title: Egypt and Turkey
results.brief_description: Visit Egypt ‘the gift of the Nile” with a recorded history of more than five thousand years and experience the antiquities of Egypt such as the Sphinx and Great Pyramid in Giza. Travel to Cairo with its contrast of most modern city in the Middle East, but also mirror to an ancient past in bazaars, antiquities and museums. Visit also Alexandria once ruled by Alexander the Great and Cleopatra. In Turkey, visit Istanbul and the Turquoise Coast. Istanbul spans two continents and has been the capital of three empires: Byzantine, Holy Roman and Ottoman. Walk through the city’s old sector to see the monuments of these cultures.

results.title: Egretta
results.brief_description: A life history of the four species of egrets commonly found in Australia, the white egret, the great egret, the white crane and the white heron.

results.title: Egghead's robot (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Milo Lewis, Cecil Musk and Australian Council for Children's Film and Television
results.brief_description: A very funny comedy about Paul “Egghead” Wentworth, the son of an inventor, who makes a look-alike robot to do his chores and replace him at sports. All goes well until the robot is named “cricketer of the year”, then blows a fuse in the compost heap! Written by Leif Saxon. Rated: G

results.title: Effective resumes: resumes for maximum impact
results.creator_credit: Susan Richardson, Robert Richardson Jr and Riverside Productions
results.brief_description: This American video addresses the need for every job seeker (in particular young people), to have a resume and methods for laying it out, presentation and content. It presents tips for achieving an edge over other applicants.

holdings.name: VHS; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: Film technique: editing. Parts 1 and 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Explains the editor’s responsibilities and summarises the various stages of editing. The first part deals mainly with the editing of silent films. The second part is more complex and discusses the editing of film with sound and synchronising sound and picture. Intended for film and TV trainees and technical colleges.

results.title: Acting
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Shows a stage actor during audition and his transition to a motion picture actor. Well known actors including Helen Hayes, Vincent Price, Henry Fonda, Jim Backus, Jean Stapleton, Jeff Corey, Royal Dano, Mariette Hartley, Janet McLachlan and Paul Newman appear and discuss problem areas that a film actor must deal with.

results.title: Edward scissorhands [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Tim Burton, Denise Di Novi and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A lonely old inventor in a castle upon a hill dies and leaves his greatest creation, a boy called Edward, unfinished. Instead of hands, the boy has sharp shears of metal. Until his rescue by a kindly Avon lady who takes him home to the pastel paradise of suburbia, Edward lives alone in darkness. “Edward Scissorhands” is more than a fairy tale by masterful director Tim Burton. This is a satire/allegory which is both funny and moving. Johnny Depp as Edward is a gentle creature full of pathos, yet dignified; much less a monster than the fickle humans who at first embrace him and then seek to destroy him. Dianne Weist stars as Avon Lady Peg, and Winona Ryder as her daughter, Kim. The sets are typical of Burton’s famed surreal style. “Edward Scissorhands” is a film of great poignancy with its own special beauty.
